DOCNAME: CASE OF TSONYO TSONEV v. BULGARIA (No. 2)
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6+6-3-c - Right to a fair trial (Article 6-1 - Fair hearing;Equality of arms) (Article 6 - Right to a fair trial;Article 6-3-c - Defence through legal assistance;Free legal assistance;Legal assistance of his own choosing;Required by interests of justice);No violation of Article 6+6-3-b - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing) (Article 6-3-b - Adequate time;Preparation of defence;Article 6 - Right to a fair trial);No violation of Article 6+6-3-c - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing) (Article 6-3-c - Defence through legal assistance;Free legal assistance;Insufficient means;Required by interests of justice;Article 6 - Right to a fair trial);Violation of Article 4 of Protocol No. 7 - Right not to be tried or punished twice-{general};Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . At the relevant time he was unemployed .

CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the applicant and PERSON , after having consumed alcohol , went to the flat of PERSON , apparently with the intention of recovering certain items which Mr PERSON ’s former girlfriend had left there . A violent incident ensued and the police , who were called by neighbours , arrested the applicant and Mr D.M.

CARDINAL . On DATE a police officer drew up a report describing the applicant ’s conduct on the previous evening . On the basis of this report , in a decision of CARDINAL DATE the mayor of GPE found the applicant guilty of breaching section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of municipal by - law no . CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and fined him MONEY ( ORG ) . The mayor explained that , while drunk , the applicant had broken down the door of PERSON flat and had beaten him up . These actions had constituted a breach of public order and an expression of manifest disregard towards society , contrary to the above - mentioned provision . The decision , which specified that it was subject to judicial review within DATE after being served on the offender , was not served on the applicant , whose address was unknown . It was put in the file and considered as constructively served under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Administrative Offences and Penalties Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant did not learn about it within the timelimit for seeking judicial review and the decision became final .

CARDINAL . NORP Some time later the prosecution authorities charged the applicant with inflicting “ intermediate ” bodily harm on Mr G.I. , contrary to LAW , and breaking into his home , contrary to LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . They alleged that he had acted in concert with Mr D.M.

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s trial took place before FAC TIME on DATE and between CARDINAL p.m. and TIME on DATE . He was represented by CARDINAL lawyers . It is unclear whether they were retained by him or appointed by the court . The court heard the QUANTITY coaccused , CARDINAL experts and CARDINAL witnesses . It admitted numerous documents in evidence and heard the parties’ closing argument .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of inflicting “ intermediate ” bodily harm on Mr G.I. It found him not guilty of committing this offence in concert with others and not guilty of entering another ’s home by force . It sentenced him to QUANTITY . The court found that PERSON alone had broken down the door of PERSON flat and that the applicant had entered the flat after him . The court further found that in the ensuing scuffle the applicant had broken CARDINAL of Mr G.I. ’s teeth , which amounted to “ intermediate ” bodily harm , but at the same time held that in committing this act the applicant had not acted in concert with PERSON , because the latter had not hit Mr G.I. in the head .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG . He drafted the appeal himself . Mr D.M. did not appeal .

CARDINAL . ORG held a hearing on TIME . The counsel previously appointed by the court for the applicant did not show up and new counsel was thus appointed . The applicant said that the new counsel was acquainted with his arguments and the case , and that he agreed to be defended by her . The record of the hearing says that the newly appointed counsel took TIME to acquaint herself with the file ; according to the applicant , she only had TIME to do so , because , as shown by the record , the hearing started at TIME and finished at TIME

CARDINAL . In her closing speech , counsel for the applicant argued that it was not certain whether he had hit Mr G.I. in the head . Even if that had been so , he had done so in selfdefence , because Mr G.I. had tried to shoot him with a gas pistol and he had panicked . It was furthermore unclear whether the blows allegedly administered by the applicant could result in the type of injuries sustained by Mr G.I. The experts’ statements on this point had not been properly recorded . Counsel later filed a memorial previously drawn up by the applicant .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG upheld the lower court ’s judgment . It found that it had assessed the evidence properly and had established the facts correctly , and went on to say that there was no indication that the applicant had acted in selfdefence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed on points of law , again drafting the appeal himself . On DATE he asked ORG to appoint counsel for him . He relied on LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and asserted that he had no legal knowledge and could not afford to retain counsel , whereas the interests of justice required that he be legally represented because he risked imprisonment .
CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE the president of ORG of ORG advised the applicant that it was not possible to appoint counsel for him , as the prerequisites of LAW were not met .

CARDINAL . ORG held a hearing on DATE . The applicant acted pro se . The prosecution argued that his appeal should be dismissed . On DATE ORG , which had the power to quash , vary or reverse the lower court ’s judgment , decided to uphold it . It found that the lower court had properly established the facts , had fully examined all relevant issues , and had not breached the rules of procedure .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW makes it an offence to inflict “ intermediate ” bodily harm on another . LAW defines “ intermediate ” bodily harm as , among other things , the knocking out of teeth whose loss makes chewing or speaking more difficult .

CARDINAL . By LAW , it is an offence to enter another person ’s home using force , threats , dexterity , abuse of power , or special technical devices . LAW provides that the offence is aggravated if it has been committed at TIME or by an armed individual .

CARDINAL . Points ( CARDINAL ) to ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE Code of Criminal Procedure listed situations in which the appointment of counsel for the accused was mandatory : ( i ) the accused was a minor ; ( ii ) the accused suffered from a disability preventing him or her from defending himself or herself in person ; ( iii ) the accused was charged with an offence punishable by PERCENT ten years’ imprisonment ; ( iv ) the accused did not speak NORP ; ( v ) another accused who had diverging interests had already retained counsel ; or ( vi ) the case was heard in the absence of the accused . On DATE a new point ( CARDINAL ) was added . It was part of a comprehensive overhaul of the LAW intended to bring it in line with the LAW , based on LAW ( c ) , and it provided that the appointment of counsel was compulsory if the accused could not afford it but wished to be legally represented and the interests of justice so required .

CARDINAL . On DATE the DATE Code was superseded by DATE Code of Criminal Procedure . The text of its LAW ( CARDINAL ) matches exactly that of LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . LAW provides that the participation of counsel in the proceedings before ORG is compulsory . Where the participation of counsel is compulsory , the competent authority has to appoint counsel when not retained by the accused ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Code provided that a hearing had to be adjourned if counsel for the accused failed to appear and if such counsel could not be replaced without causing prejudice to the accused ’s defence .

CARDINAL . In DATE the text was amended , providing that an adjournment was only necessary where the case could not proceed without the accused being legally represented . In a decision of DATE ( решение № CARDINAL от CARDINAL април DATE г. по к. д. № DATE г. обн. , GPE , бр. CARDINAL от CARDINAL април DATE г. ) ORG declared the amendment unconstitutional , finding that it made it possible to hold hearings in which the accused would not be legally represented and that this would certainly prejudice the defence . It was true that certain limitations on the rights of the defence were permissible under LAW in the interest of the proper administration of justice . However , this particular limitation was disproportionate , because it made it harder to ascertain the truth and put the accused at a disadvantage vis - à - vis the prosecution , in breach of the principle of equality of arms .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( whose text has been copied almost verbatim into LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Code ) provided that criminal proceedings could not be opened or had to be discontinued if in respect of the same person and in respect of the same offence there existed a final judgment or decision . The former ORG DATE in a binding interpretative decision – , and later ORG , have construed this provision as not barring the opening of criminal proceedings in respect of persons who have already been punished in administrative proceedings ( тълк. реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL ноември DATE г. по н. д. № DATE г. , ORG ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL май DATE г. по н. д. № DATE г. , ORG , ORG н. о. ; и ORG № CARDINAL от CARDINAL декември DATE г. по н. д. № CARDINAL г. , ORG , I ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Bylaw no . CARDINAL for safeguarding public order on the territory of the municipality of GPE ( GPE № CARDINAL за опазване на обществения ред на територията на габровската община , приета с решение № CARDINAL , протокол № CARDINAL от CARDINAL март DATE г. ) was adopted by ORG on DATE pursuant to section CARDINAL ) of the DATE ORG LAW , which , as worded at the material time , empowered municipal councils to make bylaws concerning local issues . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the bylaw provided that citizens were prohibited from committing acts which breached public order and expressed manifest disregard towards society . Section ORG ) provided that violations of the by - law were punishable with a fine of up to BGN CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL of the bylaw , the procedure for establishing such violations and their punishment was governed by ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Administrative Offences and Penalties Act provides that municipal councils may , in issuing bylaws , determine the elements of administrative offences and provide for penalties among those envisaged by ORG of DATE . Under section CARDINAL ) of that LAW , as in force at the material time , the breach of a municipal by - law was punishable with a fine of MONEY .

CARDINAL . The DATE Act governs administrative offences and penalties and lays down the procedure for punishing such offences . It defines them , in section CARDINAL , as acts or omissions which run counter to the established order , have been committed wilfully and are punishable with administrative penalties . LAW provides that , absent specific provisions in the LAW , the DATE LAW governs all questions concerning mens rea , capacity , exculpating circumstances , complicity , preparation and attempts .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , a decision imposing an administrative penalty must be served on the offender . If , however , the offender can not be found at the address he specified and his new address is unknown , a note to this effect is made on the decision and it is considered as served on the date of the note ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The decision may be challenged by way of judicial review ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) within DATE after it has been served ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Under section CARDINAL , decisions imposing administrative penalties become final when ( i ) they are not subject to review , ( ii ) have not been challenged within the statutory timelimit , or ( iii ) have been challenged but have been upheld or varied by the competent court .
